message_1: A retail store and an online retailer are both selling a product for $100. The retail store incurs a cost of $50 per unit while the online retailer incurs a cost of $60 per unit in delivering the product. If both the retailers can set any price they want, what will be their final selling price and profit margin?
message_2:
Since both retailers can set any price they want, let's assume they keep the selling price at $100 for simplicity.

For the retail store:
Selling price = $100
Cost per unit = $50

Profit per unit = Selling price - Cost per unit
Profit per unit = $100 - $50 = $50

Profit margin = (Profit per unit / Selling price) * 100
Profit margin = ($50 / $100) * 100 = 50%

For the online retailer:
Selling price = $100
Cost per unit = $60

Profit per unit = Selling price - Cost per unit
Profit per unit = $100 - $60 = $40

Profit margin = (Profit per unit / Selling price) * 100
Profit margin = ($40 / $100) * 100 = 40%

So, if both retailers keep the selling price at $100, the retail store will have a profit margin of 50%, and the online retailer will have a profit margin of 40%.
